I retired from the Army before 9/11, so anything I say about Afghanistan would be as simply an historical observer.  But I did serve on missions that were conducted by my Cavalry Squadron and micromanaged by politicians.  These were by and large successes as far as my unit achieving the stated goals of the mission.  But in the long run, due mainly to the stupidity of politicians, the missions failed.  This is due to the short sightedness of the politicians.  An example of this is UNMIH, the “United Nations Mission In Haiti”.  We were given the mission, “Provide a stable environment for free and fail elections.”  So we did that, and Haiti’s national elections went off rather smoothly.  Then the politician declared victory, we left, the Haitian people ousted the elected President, reinstalled the previous dictator and we now still have Haitian boat people showing us in Florida, 35 years after we allegedly solved Haiti’s problems.

If our military personnel are questioning whether their sacrifice was worth it or not and having a hard time coming up with an answer, I humbly suggest that is because what they were doing was outside the scope of legitimate US military activity. Our military exists to protect US citizens and defend the Constitution. Not to protect political interests, not to defend other countries, and not to act as the world's police force. That is the UN's job, not ours, and it is not our job to pick up their slack if they don't do their job.
If our military personnel want to feel assured that their sacrifice is worth it, make sure that you fulfill your sworn oath by your actions, and refuse orders that lead you astray from that oath. Protect American citizens. Defend the Constitution from attacks both foreign AND DOMESTIC. Because while you were all off fighting Afghanistan's war, Marxists were here infiltrating our government at the highest levels (including the military) and are *right now* perpetrating the largest attack on the Constitution that has ever occurred.
